Today is mark to market day for investments, 30 Sept. Can anyone with an accounting background help here? Uber marked the value of their 12% stake in Didi on 30 June, when Didi's market cap was 67 billion, so about 8 billion?Then two days later Didi starts to fall to its current market cap of 38 billion, making Uber's 12% worth 4.56 billion.On the last earning report, Uber reduced the appearance of its losses by marking up the Didi stake by 1.47 billion. Will it now have to mark the value of that stake down, and by how much? 8 billion - 4.56 billion= 3.44 billion? Or what?

All that the Drizly acquisition signifies is the current management is helpless to grow to profits in mobility, and are throwing more money at buying revenues in delivery. I think everyone can agree that delivery is a money losing business, with very low margins in the best of cases, and ruthless competitors in DoorDash. Dara K is lost, in charge of a lost cause. He is very good at looking into camera lenses and promising fake adjusted ebidta profits soon, very soon. Those, however, don't include stock based compensation, and a long list of other costs. BS.

So is Uber stock a buy at current levels of $46.50 per share? I think it is. Uber trades at just about 5.5x projected 2021 revenues, while its smaller ride-hailing rival Lyft LYFT trades at a slightly higher 6x multiple, and food delivery rival DoorDash trades at around 16x. Both companies are likely to grow revenues at a slower pace compared to Uber Revenues over the next year. Moreover, Uber stock also remains down by about 8% year-to-date and by almost 25% from its February 2021 highs, compared to the broader Nasdaq-100, which is up by about 21% over the same period, potentially presenting a good entry point for investors. I value Uber stock at about $50 per share, marking a 7% premium over the current market price.

Some people are concerned with the short term price fluctuations. I’m not really. There are momentum factors working against the stock right now. Regulatory issues such as employee vs contractor. These are short term issues that obscure the long term thesis. A market leader is a high growth industry this is a long term winner. $200 in 3-5 years is very possible. Don’t make the mistake I made with Facebook and sell too early when this hits $64. Sure it’s always prudent to take some profits but this will be a core holding for me.
